>What was the text? Any good?

Seemed OK, it is a very basic intro:

         "Development"
         Edited by Brian Goodwin
         Published by Hodder and Stoughton/The Open University
         ISBN 0-340-53190-8

It's from 1991 and the OU tend to update their course-texts pretty often, 
so there's probably a newer one by now...


>I just came across this:
>
>-------------------------------
>
>*Biophysics of Computation: Information Processing in Single Neurons
>(Computational Neuroscience), Chistoff Koch*
>
>*Book Description*
>Neural network research often builds on the fiction that neurons are
>simple linear threshold units, completely neglecting the highly dynamic
>and complex nature of synapses, dendrites, and voltage-dependent ionic
>currents. Biophysics of Computation: Information Processing in Single
>Neurons challenges this notion, using richly detailed experimental and
>theoretical findings from cellular biophysics to explain the repertoire
>of computational functions available to single
>neurons. The author shows how individual nerve cells can multiply,
>integrate, or delay synaptic inputs and how information can be encoded
>in the voltage across the membrane, in the intracellular calcium
>concentration, or in the timing of individual spikes.
>-------------------------------
>
>Sounds like just the ticket. Also there are some chapters online in
>postscript form at http://www.klab.caltech.edu/~koch/biophysics-book/
><http://www.klab.caltech.edu/%7Ekoch/biophysics-book/>

That's interesting.  Of course, the biophysics of the nerve-cell is a very 
different approach to take from the developmental biology of nerve 
growth.  Sort of like the difference between taking a VCR apart or spying 
on the factory it comes from....

         Ian
